item.title: One Of The Most Popular Games In The World Will Be Free On Xbox This Weekend
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The new year has barely begun, but Xbox Game Pass Ultimate, Premium, and Essential subscribers are getting their first Free Play Days of 2026 this weekend. From January 15-18, players who participate in the event will get to play one of the most popular sports games in the world, EA Sports FC 26, for free.

To get the word out, EA and Xbox shared a video of retired German soccer player Toni Kroos--who played for Real Madrid for a decade--working the phones and reconnecting with people.

Game Pass Premium and Essential cost $15 and $10 a month, respectively. However, Microsoft is currently running a special deal that will let players try Premium for 14 days for only $1. Essential is also getting a $1 preview period, but for 30 days instead of 14. Unfortunately, Game Pass Ultimate isn't getting a discount at this time and the price remains $30 per month.

According to research company Newzoo, EA Sports FC 26 was the console game that generated the most revenue in 2025 in terms of international sales through the end of November. Among PC games, EA Sports FC 26 placed sixth overall.

EA Sports FC 26 was reviewed by GameSpot in September 2025, and it received a 7/10 score. Our review noted that it was a marked improvement over its predecessor, EA FC 25, while also acknowledging its imperfections: "There are flaws on and off the pitch, yet this is the best the series has been for a short while. It might not walk away with a trophy this year, but it's getting closer to glory."

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Roblox Has Added Facial Age Verification, With Very Mixed Results
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Roblox has begun the global rollout of its facial age-check system, which will be required for all players who want to access in-game chat. The rollout has not gone smoothly so far, with some players' ages being wildly miscalculated, others finding workarounds, and some flat out refusing to engage with the verification system due to privacy concerns.

Roblox's age verification system first started rolling out in Australia, New Zealand, and the Netherlands in early December, and now will be extended to all regions where chat is available. The AI-powered age check, which estimates a user's age by analyzing their face, must be completed to unlock chat features. Users over 13 have the option of verifying their age using ID instead.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: WTF Is Going On With Roblox? | Spot On

The estimated ages are used by Roblox to lock off chat with users who are outside of a person's age range--for example, a 13-year-old can chat with users between the ages of nine and 17, while a 16-year-old can chat with users aged 13-20. The new age check is designed to safeguard children from predators, following intense scrutiny on Roblox from legislators, the media, and concerned parents. However, users have quickly proven how easily it can be bypassed.

Wired reports finding Roblox accounts that have been age-verified as young as nine for sale on ebay, while Roblox has acknowledged that some parents are age-checking for their children, resulting in their accounts being sorted into the 21+ age group. Social media is rife with videos of players using different tactics to bypass the age check, including using virtual avatars, photographs of celebrities, or even drawing on facial hair and wrinkles. Last year, when Discord and Reddit implemented age verification in certain regions, users discovered that Death Stranding 2's Norman Reedus could be used to bypass certain AI-powered facial age checks.

Alongside those intentionally trying to fool the system, other Roblox users who have tried to engage with the system legitimately have found that the AI age estimation is often inaccurate. Multiple social media posts show users who claim to be over the age of 18 being categorized in the 13-15 year old category, while others claim that siblings as young as 10 have been sorted into older age categories.

Some users have flat-out refused to engage with the age verification system at all, choosing to leave chat features locked due to privacy concerns with the AI verification software. YouTuber Schlep, known for his content around safety in Roblox, posted a warning that the company providing Roblox's age-verification service, Persona, is currently being sued over privacy and data safety concerns.

Overall, players aren't happy with the new policy, with some choosing to protest in game. In its blog post about the new system, Roblox says that "more than 50% of daily active users" have completed age verification in the regions where it was rolled out in early December--a relatively low percentage considering over 40% of players have instead chosen to go without chat features for over a month. Whether the age check will improve safety concerns on the beleaguered platform remains to be seen.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
